item.title: [GROOVY-6887] AutoClone issue with CompileStatic
item.description:

import groovy.transform.AutoClone
import groovy.transform.CompileStatic

@CompileStatic
@AutoClone
class Event {
   Long timeStamp = -1
}

println Event        // OK
println new Event()  // VerifyError

comments.comment: This is trying to isolate a part of the issue from http://jira.codehaus.org/browse/GROOVY-6877
I think if you use just long vs Long it might opens up some more issues.

I am specifically avoiding using long to ensure that I am covering just one issue. As a general rule for most open source projects, the likelihood and speed of fixes is inversely proportional to the complexity of the test case, so the simpler the better. Using long can be addressed subsequently (often best in a separate issue) with a view to working out whether it is also a problem when combining the two annotations or just one specifically.

Some things which turning on static type checking debug mode reveals (which can be fixed easy enough with some casts etc. within the AST transform):

// [Static type checking] - Error in generated code [_result.timeStamp] - No such property: timeStamp for class: java.lang.Object
// [Static type checking] - Error in generated code [super.clone()] - Cannot assign value of type java.lang.Object to variable of type EventBase
// [Static type checking] - Error in generated code [timeStamp.clone()] - Cannot assign value of type java.lang.Object to variable of type java.lang.Long

but they still don't address the principal issue which is that CompileStatic doesn't like calling the protected super.clone().

After altering the AST transform code to fix those initial errors it now gives:

[Static type checking] - Error in generated code [(java.lang.Cloneable) timeStamp] - Inconvertible types: cannot cast java.lang.Long to java.lang.Cloneable

And the generated code for the clone method is:

public java.lang.Object clone() throws java.lang.CloneNotSupportedException {
    Event _result = ((super.clone()) as Event)
       if ( timeStamp instanceof java.lang.Cloneable) {
          _result .timeStamp = (((( timeStamp ) as java.lang.Cloneable).clone()) as java.lang.Long)
    }
    return _result 
}

Doesn't seem like the instanceof guard is affecting the type checkers behavior.

If something is not cloneable best is to mark it as an compile time error when using static compilation. Ideally use a mechanism outside Java cloning mechanism for speed and safety. (E.g. Inner object has the cloning logic wrong or is not clonable.)

Initial stab at a fix:
https://github.com/groovy/groovy-core/pull/458
more tests to come plus doco updates
